Important selected bond distances (Å) and angles (°): Pb1–O1 2.297(10), Pb1–O3 2.345(12), Pb1–O2<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup> (−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>+3/2,−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>−1/2,−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) 2.401(10), Pb1–O4 (<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>+1,<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) 2.488(11), Pb–O1<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup> (−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>+3/2,−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>+1/2,−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) 2.678(11); O1–Pb1–O3 85.2(4), O1–Pb1–O2<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup> 79.0(4), O3–Pb1–O2<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup> 85.9(5), O1–Pb1–O4 80.5(4), O3–Pb1–O4 92.6(4), O2<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>–Pb1–O4 159.5(4), O1–Pb1–O1<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup> 77.0(4), O3–Pb1–O1<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup> 156,2(4), O2<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>–Pb1–O1<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup> 75.4(4), O4–Pb1–O1<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup> 99.8(3); P1–O1 1.533(11), P1–O2 1.498(11), P2–O3 1.498(12), P2–O4 1.487(12).</ce:simple-para>

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">By reaction of lead(II) nitrate with <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-diphenylmethylenediphosphinic acid in water solution a new inorganic–organic hybrid of formula [Pb(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(P(Ph)O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)] has been synthesized and structurally characterized. The complex displays a polymeric columnar structure, the column being formed by two intersecting sinusoidal ribbons of lead(II) ions bridged by bifunctional phosphinate ligands. The intersections of the ribbons are constituted by dimeric units of pentacoordinated lead(II) ions.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

By reaction of lead(II) nitrate with P,P '-diphenylmethylenediphosphinic acid in water solution a new inorganic-organic hybrid of formula [Pb(CH2(P(Ph)O2)2)] has been synthesized and structurally characterized. The complex displays a polymeric columnar structure, the column being formed by two intersecting sinusoidal ribbons of lead(II) ions bridged by bifunctional phosphinate ligands. The intersections of the ribbons are constituted by dimeric units of pentacoordinated lead(II) ions.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Metal organophosphonate complexes are hybrid inorganic/organic materials of growing interest, as they can show structural typologies useful to various applications (molecular sieves, selective catalysts, absorbers, ionic exchangers, matrices for electric and magnetic devices) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Metal organophosphonate complexes are hybrid inorganic/organic materials of growing interest, as they can show structural typologies useful to various applications (molecular sieves, selective catalysts, absorbers, ionic exchangers, matrices for electric and magnetic devices) .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Already several years ago a number of monophosphinates had been found to have a strong aptitude to form metal coordination polymers, which have been used in a variety of applications (coatings and grease thickeners) . Generally these metal monophosphinates present extended chain polymeric structures with the metals linked by variously bridging phosphinate groups .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Already several years ago a number of monophosphinates had been found to have a strong aptitude to form metal coordination polymers, which have been used in a variety of applications (coatings and grease thickeners) . Generally these metal monophosphinates present extended chain polymeric structures with the metals linked by variously bridging phosphinate groups .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Recently, we have reported a series of inorganic–organic hybrids of general formula [M(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(pcp)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, where M=Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>,Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>,Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and pcp is the bifunctional P,P<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-diphenylmethylenediphosphinate ligand . These compounds constitute a series of isomorphous layered polymers, where the metal can be replaced by another metal without changing the overall structure (mixed metal polymers could be obtained indeed). In this type of complexes the water molecules, both of coordination and crystallization, play a determinant role, as they are involved through hydrogen bonding interactions in building of pluridimensional extended networks. The removing of such water molecules could represent an important challenge, in order to leave open coordination sites on the metals for possible intercalation or catalytic reactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Recently, we have reported a series of inorganic-organic hybrids of general formula [M(H2O)3(pcp)]⋅H2O, where M=Mn2+,Co2+,Ni2+ and pcp is the bifunctional P,P'-diphenylmethylenediphosphinate ligand . These compounds constitute a series of isomorphous layered polymers, where the metal can be replaced by another metal without changing the overall structure (mixed metal polymers could be obtained indeed). In this type of complexes the water molecules, both of coordination and crystallization, play a determinant role, as they are involved through hydrogen bonding interactions in building of pluridimensional extended networks. The removing of such water molecules could represent an important challenge, in order to leave open coordination sites on the metals for possible intercalation or catalytic reactions.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Now we report the synthesis and the crystal structure of a lead(II) hybrid coordination polymer with the ligand pcp, of formula [Pb(pcp)]. So far only very few examples of lead(II) containing organo-phosphonates  or -phosphinates  have been reported.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Now we report the synthesis and the crystal structure of a lead(II) hybrid coordination polymer with the ligand pcp, of formula [Pb(pcp)]. So far only very few examples of lead(II) containing organo-phosphonates  or -phosphinates  have been reported.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The [Pb(pcp)]complex has been synthesized by reacting equimolar amounts of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pcp and Pb(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in boiling water. Standing of the solution in a closed flask for a day, at 353 K, afforded colorless needle-shaped crystals suitable for an X-ray study. The compound is insoluble in water and in both polar and apolar organic solvents. (Yield, 50 mg, 63%. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calcd. for C<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Pb: C, 31.14; H, 2.41%. <ce:italic>Found</ce:italic>: C, 31.27; H, 2.45%.)</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The [Pb(pcp)]complex has been synthesized by reacting equimolar amounts of H2pcp and Pb(NO3)2 in boiling water. Standing of the solution in a closed flask for a day, at 353 K, afforded colorless needle-shaped crystals suitable for an X-ray study. The compound is insoluble in water and in both polar and apolar organic solvents. (Yield, 50 mg, 63%. Anal. Calcd. for C13H12O8P2Pb: C, 31.14; H, 2.41%. Found: C, 31.27; H, 2.45%.)

elements.content: The X-ray analysis 1 Crystal data: C 13 H 12 O 4 P 2 Pb,M=501.35, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a=29.280(7),b=5.451(3),c=23.152(5) Å, β=128.56(3)°,U=2889.5(18) A ̊ 3,Z=8,d calcd =2.305Mgm −3,μ(Mo-Kα)=11.907mm −1,F(000)=1872. A total of 1762 reflections were collected on a Enraf Nonius CAD4 automatic diffractometer with a Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.7107 Å) at 293 K. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 using the WINGX package with SIR97 , SHELX97 and ORTEPIII programs. R 1 and wR 2 are 0.048 and 0.109 respectively for 181 parameters and 1293 reflections [I>2σ(I)]. CCDC Ref. No. 202842. of the title compound revealed a polymeric structure, where the asymmetric unit is represented by the Pb(pcp) moiety. shows the environment about each lead atom, which displays a pentacoordination geometry, being surrounded by five oxygen atoms from four pcp ligands in a square pyramidal arrangement.
elements.clean_text: The X-ray analysis 1  Crystal data:  C 13 H 12 O 4 P 2 Pb,M=501.35, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a=29.280(7),b=5.451(3),c=23.152(5) Å, β=128.56(3)°,U=2889.5(18)  A  ̊  3,Z=8,d calcd =2.305Mgm -3,μ(Mo-Kα)=11.907mm -1,F(000)=1872. A total of 1762 reflections were collected on a Enraf Nonius CAD4 automatic diffractometer with a Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.7107 Å) at 293 K. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 using the WINGX package  with SIR97 , SHELX97  and ORTEPIII  programs. R 1 and wR 2 are 0.048 and 0.109 respectively for 181 parameters and 1293 reflections [I>2σ(I)]. CCDC Ref. No. 202842.   of the title compound revealed a polymeric structure, where the asymmetric unit is represented by the Pb(pcp) moiety.   shows the environment about each lead atom, which displays a pentacoordination geometry, being surrounded by five oxygen atoms from four pcp ligands in a square pyramidal arrangement.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Unlike the structure of the series reported [M(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(pcp)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (M=Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>,Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>,Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>) , there are no water molecules in the sphere of coordination of the lead nor interspersed in the lattice. Here the structure can be described as an infinite array of dimers of lead atoms (Pb⋯Pb 3.901 Å) bridged by the phosphinate arms of the pcp ligand. Each phosphinate uses all of its four oxygen atoms to link four lead atoms belonging to two contiguous dimers, thus creating a subunit established by two pcp ligands and by two lead dimers. Additionally one of the four pcp oxygen atom bridges both the leads of a dimer, so that each pcp ligand displays five bonds. The propagation of the mono-dimensional polymer along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis is represented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>. Ideally the structure can be viewed as two sinusoidal ribbons intersecting through the lead dimers. In 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor> is given the packing diagram with the view normal to [1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0], with the phenyl rings excluded for sake of clarity. In 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor> the complete packing with view normal to [0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0] evidences the shielding exerted by the organic part of the ligand, namely the phenyl rings, which dispose themselves outside the columnar array of the intersecting ribbons.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Unlike the structure of the series reported [M(H2O)3(pcp)]⋅H2O (M=Mn2+,Co2+,Ni2+) , there are no water molecules in the sphere of coordination of the lead nor interspersed in the lattice. Here the structure can be described as an infinite array of dimers of lead atoms (Pb⋯Pb 3.901 Å) bridged by the phosphinate arms of the pcp ligand. Each phosphinate uses all of its four oxygen atoms to link four lead atoms belonging to two contiguous dimers, thus creating a subunit established by two pcp ligands and by two lead dimers. Additionally one of the four pcp oxygen atom bridges both the leads of a dimer, so that each pcp ligand displays five bonds. The propagation of the mono-dimensional polymer along the b axis is represented in  . Ideally the structure can be viewed as two sinusoidal ribbons intersecting through the lead dimers. In   is given the packing diagram with the view normal to [100], with the phenyl rings excluded for sake of clarity. In   the complete packing with view normal to [010] evidences the shielding exerted by the organic part of the ligand, namely the phenyl rings, which dispose themselves outside the columnar array of the intersecting ribbons.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Concerning in particular the lead atom it is evident that the square pyramidal arrangement leaves a void in the sphere of coordination. Such hemileptic coordination with low coordination number with respect to the large size of the metal is favouring the localization of the Pb(II) lone pair , whose activity is exerted in a space shielded by the phenyl rings of the adjacent molecules. Accordingly the bond lengths Pb–O show a variety of values, as they range from 2.297(10) to 2.678(11) Å with the shortest Pb–O bond apical in the square pyramid and opposite to the void .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Concerning in particular the lead atom it is evident that the square pyramidal arrangement leaves a void in the sphere of coordination. Such hemileptic coordination with low coordination number with respect to the large size of the metal is favouring the localization of the Pb(II) lone pair , whose activity is exerted in a space shielded by the phenyl rings of the adjacent molecules. Accordingly the bond lengths Pb-O show a variety of values, as they range from 2.297(10) to 2.678(11) Å with the shortest Pb-O bond apical in the square pyramid and opposite to the void .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">On the same side of the lone pair the shortest contacts to lead atom are those relative to O2 (4.0 Å) and O3 (3.7 Å), too large according to the Shannon criterion for Pb–O interaction . The stereochemical activity of the lone pair is evidenced also by the distortion of the square pyramid, the displacement of the lead from the least-squares basal plane being 0.41 Å toward the void.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: On the same side of the lone pair the shortest contacts to lead atom are those relative to O2 (4.0 Å) and O3 (3.7 Å), too large according to the Shannon criterion for Pb-O interaction . The stereochemical activity of the lone pair is evidenced also by the distortion of the square pyramid, the displacement of the lead from the least-squares basal plane being 0.41 Å toward the void.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">As regards the pcp ligand, the P–O distances present values in perfect agreement with the nature of the bonds displayed by the ligand itself: as a matter of fact, while P1–O2, P2–O3 and P2–O4 are all practically equal to 1.50 Å (each of these acting as monodentate), P1–O1 significantly differentiates (1.53 Å), as the O1 is involved in the bonding to two metal atoms. Finally it is remarkable the aptitude of the pcp ligand to function as a binegative anion, so that while it balances the charge of metal(II) cations, it can form neutral complexes and prevent the entry into the lattice of other counterions. In fact these latter could disturb its pillaring action.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As regards the pcp ligand, the P-O distances present values in perfect agreement with the nature of the bonds displayed by the ligand itself: as a matter of fact, while P1-O2, P2-O3 and P2-O4 are all practically equal to 1.50 Å (each of these acting as monodentate), P1-O1 significantly differentiates (1.53 Å), as the O1 is involved in the bonding to two metal atoms. Finally it is remarkable the aptitude of the pcp ligand to function as a binegative anion, so that while it balances the charge of metal(II) cations, it can form neutral complexes and prevent the entry into the lattice of other counterions. In fact these latter could disturb its pillaring action.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">We recall that the unique two previously described lead(II) phosphinate polymers contain the ligand monophospinate R<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, respectively with R=Ph  and tBu ; their structures consist of polymeric chains of lead atoms linked by double phosphinate bridges.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We recall that the unique two previously described lead(II) phosphinate polymers contain the ligand monophospinate R2PO2 -, respectively with R=Ph  and tBu ; their structures consist of polymeric chains of lead atoms linked by double phosphinate bridges.

Standing of the solution in a closed flask for a day, at 353 K, afforded colorless needle-shaped crystals suitable for an X-ray study. The compound is insoluble in water and in both polar and apolar organic solvents. (Yield, 50 mg, 63%. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calcd. for C<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Pb: C, 31.14; H, 2.41%. <ce:italic>Found</ce:italic>: C, 31.27; H, 2.45%.)</ce:para>

metadata.title:
A new lead(II) inorganic–organic hybrid of the P,P
               ′-diphenylmethylene-diphosphinate ligand: synthesis and X-ray characterization of the [Pb(CH2(P(Ph)O2)2)] complex
